H0.text: Changes in popular belief revised the theory that living organisms came from nonliving objects.

H1.text: Evidence from experiments revised the theory that scientists once believed living organisms came from nonliving objects.

H2.text: Information published in books revised the theory that living organisms came from nonliving objects, a belief once held by scientists.

H3.text: Advances in the scientific method revised the theory that living organisms originated from nonliving objects, a view once held by scientists.

A4.text: Experiments conducted by Pasteur and others were thought to have refuted the conventional notion of spontaneous generation by the mid-1800s.

A5.text: Spontaneous generation was taken as scientific fact for two millennia. Though challenged in the 17th and 18th centuries by the experiments of the Italian biologists Francesco Redi and Lazzaro Spallanzani, it was not discredited until the work of the French chemist Louis Pasteur and the Irish physicist John Tyndall in the mid-19th century.
